newsitem.title: USA: Aon takes Q2 charge for losses at new unit. [CORRECTED 15:30 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Aon takes Q2 charge for losses at new unit. [CORRECTED 15:30 GMT]

text.p: Aon Corp, an insurance company, said Tuesday it took a special charge of $27.0 million pretax in the second quarter because of losses on highly volatile securities at Alexander & Alexander Services Inc (A&A), which Aon acquired in the first quarter for about $1.23 billion.
The charge amounted to $0.10 a share after tax.
Aon said it discovered that A&A's investment portfolio contained certain highly volatile securities with previously unrecognized losses.

(Corrects to clarify discovery of volatile securities) Aon said it immediately sold these particular securities and undertook a full financial investigation. That investigation into the size and causes of all losses was conducted by Aon's auditors and has just been completed.

Aon said the investigation revealed that A&A's portfolio included certainly highly volatile securities, which Aon claimed were incorrectly classified as high quality money market instruments. Aon alleged that these securities had been carried on A&A's books at inflated values at the time of the acquisition.
Aon said it contacted law enforcement authorities and is cooperating with their investigations.
Aon said the securities in question included inverse floater tranches of collateralized mortgage obligations, a mortgage derivative product.

"Naturally, we were disappointed to uncover the securities losses, which had apparently gone undetected at A&A for several years," Patrick Ryan, chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. "But we should stress that Aon does not engage in the trading of highly volatile securities."
Aon declined to comment on whether it would pursue legal action regarding the A&A acquisition.
